Circular motion

Uniform
$$\omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt} = \frac{v_T}{r}$$
$$T = \frac{2\pi}{\omega} = \frac{2\pi r}{v}$$
$$a = \frac{v^2}{r} = \omega^2r$$
$$\bar{s} = r\cos(\omega t)\bar{i} + r\sin(\omega t)\bar{j}, \mid \bar{s} \mid = r$$
$$\bar{v} = r\omega(-\sin(\omega t)\bar{i} + \cos(\omega t)\bar{j}), \mid \bar{v} \mid = \omega r$$
$$\bar{a} = -r\omega^2(\cos(\omega t)\bar{i} + \sin(\omega t)\bar{j}), \mid \bar{a} \mid = \omega^2r = \frac{v^2}{r}$$
Thus acceleration must be in towards the center

Non-uniform
$$\alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt}$$
With non-uniform, there is a non-zero tangential acceleration $a_T$ and the net acceleration is the vector sum of the centripetal acceleration $a_r$ and $a_T$.
$$a_T = r\alpha$$
